sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a Gnome2 frontend for Gnu Privacy Guard. &app; provides the following features:

&app; is an application and a project. The goal of the application is to provide an easy to use key manager and encryption capabilities. The goal of the project is to provide applications and plugins to make encryption easier for the gnome desktop.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the key manager is displayed.
The key manager window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menubar contains commands for accessing the various dialogs and windows.
The toolbar only contains commands that affect keys.
The key list shows the keys in your default key ring.
The statusbar shows operation status messages. Operations are either successful or fail.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para:
You can use the &app; application to perform the following tasks:
While &app; is in use, do not make any changes to the key ring with another program. External changes could have unkown and possibly undesirable affects.

sect2.title: Generating a Key
sect2.para:
To generate a key, choose
File New . The Generate Key dialog is displayed. You will need to choose a , , and a passphrase.

sect2.title: Exporting a Key
sect2.para:
To export a key, select a key from the list and then choose
File Save As , or click Save As. The Export Key dialog is displayed. Enter a filename, or select Export to Text, then click OK. The public key will then be exported to the file or text.
sect2.warning: If is not enabled, exported text will not display properly.

sect2.title: Importing Key(s)
sect2.para:
To import key(s), choose
File Import . The Import Key(s) dialog is displayed. Enter a filename, or select Import from Text and paste the text in, then click OK. If the file or text contains any keys, they will be imported into the key ring. The status bar will show the number of keys imported.

sect2.title: File Manager
sect2.para:
To use the File Manager, choose
File File Manager .

sect2.title: Key Properties
sect2.para:
To view key properties, select a key from the list and choose
Edit Properties , or click Properties. The Key Properties window is displayed. The following properties are shown:
Fingerprint
The unique fingerprint of the key.

sect3.title: Owner Trust / Key Validity
sect3.para:
The following Trust and Validity levels are available:
Unknown Never Marginal Full Ultimate
Personally generated keys are given Ultimate Trust and Validity by default.

sect3.title: Key Attributes
sect3.para:
Attributes that exist for every key are:
Key ID
The key's ID.
Created
The creation date of the key.

sect3.title: Key Type
sect3.para:
The key type is determined by it's Algorithm and its other primary and sub keys. The following algorithms are available:
DSA
This is the default type for a primary key in a key pair. It can also be a sub key. The length ranges from 512 to 1024.
ElGamal
This key is only available as a sub key and is the default sub key type in a key pair. The length ranges from 768 to 4096.
RSA
This key can be a primary key and a sub key. The length ranges from 1024 to 4096.
sect3.note: Keys without ElGamal subkeys do not have encryption capabilities.

sect3.title: Key Expiration
sect3.para: Each key has a unique expiration date. That date can be either an exact date or Never.

sect3.title: User ID
sect3.para:
A user ID consists of the following parts:
Name
A name or handle of key's owner.
Email
A (hopefully) valid email address associated with the key.
Comment
A comment about the key, or ID.

sect2.para: Below the are the subkeys (if any). Subkeys have the same as a primary key, but can also be deleted and revoked.

The following key operations are available:

sect2.title: Deleting a Key
sect2.para:
To delete a key, choose
Edit Delete . The Delete Key dialog is displayed. Click Yes to delete the key.

sect3.title: Passphrase Entry
sect3.para: This dialog is displayed when a passphrase must be entered. The key for which the passphrase is needed is shown above the entry.

sect3.title: Signatures
sect3.para: This dialog shows the signatures and their status of the verified data.

sect3.title: Recipients
sect3.para: Use this dialog to select multiple recipeints. Currently this used for exporting keys and encrypting data. Encryption requires that keys have at least Full Validity: .

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para:
To show the preferences, choose
Settings Preferences . The Preferences dialog is displayed.
Ascii Armor
Ascii armor ensures that data is encoded in ASCII text, not binary. This is on by default.
Text Mode
Check this to use Canonical Text Mode. This setting is not really necessary and doesn't have much effect.
Default Key
This is the default key to be used for signing.
